prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request about 20 min on-source time for each science goal. This will achieve a 1 sigma rms noise levels of ~6.5 mJy/beam km/s for each frequency setting with a velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s. Proposed molecular line observations with the ALMA will able to achieve much better mass sensitivity in gas (orders of 10^-6 to 10^-5 Mo with the velocity resolution of 0.05 km/s) as compared with the mass sensitivity achieved with the SMA in dust (3.6x10^-3 Mo with 5 sigma). Moreover, after spectral line subtraction and combined with all, approximately 1.5 GHz bandwidth of line free channel can be used for the continuum imaging. That can expect the 1 sigma noise level of ~0.1 mJy/beam, corresponds to the 5 sigma mass sensitivity of 0.008 Mo.

CO, SiO, HCO+, and DCO+ will be simultaneously observed in this science goal. We request velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s for dense gas tracers and ~0.2 km/s for outflow tracers in order to sufficiently resolve the expected velocity structures. The expected velocity variation caused by infalling/rotational motions across the envelope/disk (50<R<600AU) is of the order of 2 km/s, assuming a 0.1Mo central stellar mass. Moreover, the velocity dispersion expected from 20 K thermal gas within the sub-clumps, will be 0.28 km/s.

We will use HCO+ as tracers for envelope and molecular outflow. As a dense gas tracer, the fine velocity resolution of 0.06 km/s will be required for detecting thermal motion. In the same time, a wide-velocity coverage (>>50 km/s) will be necessary for the outflow tracers (CO and SiO) since we already know that the outflow velocity is at least extended up to 25 km/s in one side (Takahashi & Ho 2012). Therefore, we request a larger data rate (15.26 MB/s) than those recommended in the technical handbook (12MB/s). To decrease the data rate as much as possible, we apply a spectral averaging factor of 2 and we select only half of the channels for the two spectral windows that include density tracers (HCO+ and DCO+).

In order to sufficiently resolve the substructures with sizes of <120AU, a resolution better than 0.1" is required. We request here 0.9" (or 37.5AU) which is god enough and that do not require a very extended antenna configuration. At the same time, short spacing antennas are crucial for obtaining extended emission from molecular outflow as well as the extended disk/envelope structures (~1200 AU). This science goal is for the high-angular resolution observation.

x- Requested Sensitivity: We request about 20 min on-source time for each science goal. This will achieve a 1 sigma rms noise levels of ~6.5 mJy/beam km/s for each frequency setting with a velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s. Proposed molecular line observations with the ALMA will able to achieve much better mass sensitivity in gas (orders of 10^-6 to 10^-5 Mo with the velocity resolution of 0.05 km/s) as compared with the mass sensitivity achieved with the SMA in dust (3.6x10^-3 Mo with 5 sigma). Moreover, after spectral line subtraction and combined with all, approximately 1.5 GHz bandwidth of line free channel can be used for the continuum imaging. That can expect the 1 sigma noise level of ~0.1 mJy/beam, corresponds to the 5 sigma mass sensitivity of 0.008 Mo.

D13CO+, HCN, HC15N, and CS will be simultaneously observed in this science goal. We request velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s for dense gas tracers and ~0.2 km/s for outflow tracers, in order to sufficiently resolve the expected velocity structures. The expected velocity variation caused by infalling/rotational motions across the envelope/disk (50<R<600AU) is of the order of 2 km/s, assuming a 0.1Mo central stellar mass. Moreover, the velocity dispersion expected from 20 K thermal gas within the sub-clumps, will be 0.28 km/s.

We will use HCN as tracers for envelope and molecular outflow. As a dense gas tracer, the finest velocity resolution of 0.05 km/s will be required for detecting thermal motion. In the same time, a wide-velocity coverage (>>50 km/s) will be necessary for the outflow since we already know that the outflow velocity is at least extended up to 25 km/s in one side (Takahashi & Ho 2012). Therefore, we request sligthly larger data rate (12.62 MB/s) than those recommended in the technical handbook (12MB/s).

In order to sufficiently resolve the substructures with sizes of <120AU, a resolution better than 0.1" is required. We request here 0.9" (or 37.5AU) which is god enough and that do not require a very extended antenna configuration. At the same time, short spacing antennas are crucial for obtaining extended emission from molecular outflow as well as the extended disk/envelope structures (~1200 AU). This science goal is for the high-angular resolution observation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO-SiO-HCO+-DCO+large-scale
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 1st Frequency setup; focus on extended structures (C34-5+C34-1 or C34-2)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request about 20 min on-source time for each science goal. This will achieve a 1 sigma rms noise levels of ~6.5 mJy/beam km/s for each frequency setting with a velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s. Proposed molecular line observations with the ALMA will able to achieve much better mass sensitivity in gas (orders of 10^-6 to 10^-5 Mo with the velocity resolution of 0.05 km/s) as compared with the mass sensitivity achieved with the SMA in dust (3.6x10^-3 Mo with 5 sigma). Moreover, after spectral line subtraction and combined with all, approximately 1.5 GHz bandwidth of line free channel can be used for the continuum imaging. That can expect the 1 sigma noise level of ~0.1 mJy/beam, corresponds to the 5 sigma mass sensitivity of 0.008 Mo.

CO, SiO, HCO+, and DCO+ will be simultaneously observed in this science goal. We request velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s for dense gas tracers and ~0.2 km/s for outflow tracers, in order to sufficiently resolve the expected velocity structures. The expected velocity variation caused by infalling/rotational motions across the envelope/disk (50<R<600AU) is of the order of 2 km/s, assuming a 0.1Mo central stellar mass. Moreover, the velocity dispersion expected from 20 K thermal gas within the sub-clumps, will be 0.28 km/s.

We will use HCO+ as tracers for envelope and molecular outflow. As a dense gas tracer, the fine velocity resolution of 0.06 km/s will be required for detecting thermal motion. In the same time, a wide-velocity coverage (>>50 km/s) will be necessary for the outflow tracers (CO and SiO) since we already know that the outflow velocity is at least extended up to 25 km/s in one side (Takahashi & Ho 2012). Therefore, we request a larger data rate (16.79 MB/s) than those recommended in the technical handbook (12MB/s). To decrease the data rate as much as possible, we apply a spectral averaging factor of 2 and we select only half of the channels for the two spectral windows that include density tracers (HCO+ and DCO+).

In order to sufficiently resolve the substructures with sizes of <120AU, a resolution better than 0.1" is required. At the same time, short spacing antennas are crucial for obtaining extended emission from molecular outflow as well as the extended disk/envelope structures (~1200 AU). This science goal is for imaging emission with moderately high-angular resolution (0.22") with the relatively extended emission (up to 7.6"). Additional ACA (7-array + Total power array) observation will be also requested in order to obtain total flux.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CS-HCN-HC15N-D13CO+large-scale
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 2nd frequency setup; focus on compact structures (C34-5 + C34-1 or C34-2)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: - Requested Sensitivity: We request 20 min on-source time for each science goal. This will achieve a 1 sigma rms noise levels of ~6.5 mJy/beam km/s for each frequency setting with a velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s. Proposed molecular line observations with the ALMA will able to achieve much better mass sensitivity in gas (orders of 10^-6 to 10^-5 Mo with the velocity resolution of 0.05 km/s) as compared with the mass sensitivity achieved with the SMA in dust (3.6x10^-3 Mo with 5 sigma). Moreover, after spectral line subtraction and combined with all, approximately 1.5 GHz bandwidth of line free channel can be used for the continuum imaging. That can expect the 1 sigma noise level of ~0.1 mJy/beam, corresponds to the 5 sigma mass sensitivity of 0.008 Mo.

D13CO+, HCN, HC15N, and CS will be simultaneously observed in this science goal. We request velocity resolution of ~0.05 km/s for dense gas tracers and ~0.2 km/s for outflow tracers, in order to sufficiently resolve the expected velocity structures. The expected velocity variation caused by infalling/rotational motions across the envelope/disk (50<R<600AU) is of the order of 2 km/s, assuming a 0.1Mo central stellar mass. Moreover, the velocity dispersion expected from 20 K thermal gas within the sub-clumps, will be 0.28 km/s.

We will use HCN as tracers for envelope and molecular outflow. As a dense gas tracer, the finest velocity resolution of 0.05 km/s will be required for detecting thermal motion. In the same time, a wide-velocity coverage (>>50 km/s) will be necessary for the outflow since we already know that the outflow velocity is at least extended up to 25 km/s in one side (Takahashi & Ho 2012). Therefore, we request a slightly larger data rate (12.62 MB/s) than those recommended in the technical handbook (12MB/s).

In order to sufficiently resolve the substructures with sizes of <120AU, a resolution better than 0.1" is required. At the same time, short spacing antennas are crucial for obtaining extended emission from molecular outflow as well as the extended disk/envelope structures (~1200 AU). This science goal is for imaging emission with moderately high-angular resolution (0.22") with the relatively extended emission (up to 7.6"). Additional ACA (7-array + Total power array) observations will be also requested in order to obtain total flux.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Studies of intermediate-mass (IM) protostellar cores are important to extend our knowledge not only for IM-protostars, but also to find the missing link between massive- and low-mass star-formation. Here, we propose Band 7 observations of molecular lines and dust continuum emission toward the youngest IM-protostellar core intensively studied by Takahashi & Ho (2012) and Takahashi et al. (2012). The main goals of the proposal are (i) to study the gas kinematics at the densest part of the core: aim to directly image Keplerian disk, infalling envelope, and base of the outflow/jets with the angular resolution of 0.12 (50 AU), (ii) to reveal the origin of substructures within the massive disk/envelope (~1200 AU), and investigate their origin. ALMA provides significant sensitivity improvement and high-fidelity images. This will allow us to reveal the detailed formation processes in the IM protostar with the highest angular resolution ever achieved with the submillimeter wavelengths.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
